summary: An informative documentary about the history, risks, and modern regulations of asbestos, highlighting its impact on health and the environment.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen displaying the word "ASBESTOS" in white capital letters, setting a serious tone. It then transitions to a group of five individuals dressed in colorful, fringed costumes, standing in a room with a blue wall and a radiator, suggesting a retro or theatrical setting. The scene shifts to a person in a black and white dress dancing joyfully in a field of yellow flowers with mountains in the background, accompanied by the text "ASBESTOS EVERYWHERE" and "SO LOVELY," creating a stark contrast between the beauty of the scene and the ominous message. Following this, a child with curly hair, wearing a red vest and white shirt, is shown sitting at a desk with a tablet, waving at the camera in a bright, well-lit room with a clothing rack and plants in the background, indicating a casual, home environment. The video then presents an advertisement for "Mesothelioma Victims," featuring a phone number and a disclaimer stating "NOT SPONSORED," with additional text explaining the services offered by Sokolove Law, LLC, aimed at individuals affected by mesothelioma or asbestos-related cancers. The advertisement is set against a white background with red and gray accents, emphasizing the seriousness of the message. The video concludes with a return to the black screen displaying the word "ASBESTOS" in white capital letters, reinforcing the central theme of the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing asbestos. He states that people born before the 80s would know about asbestos because "it was everywhere," while those born later would know about it due to its link to mesothelioma. He adopts a somewhat serious tone, suggesting that people who were exposed to it should call a lawyer.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen that transitions to a classroom scene filled with empty desks and chairs, overlaid with the word "TODAY" in large yellow letters. The scene shifts to a dark background with question marks and the text "WHAT IS ASBESTOS" in yellow, followed by a close-up of a white powdery substance labeled "TALC" in yellow letters. An animated character is then shown sitting in a room filled with barrels marked with radiation symbols, appearing tired and writing on a piece of paper. The video then displays a close-up of a microchip and a piece of black rock, followed by a collection of colorful glass bottles on a wooden surface. A news article headline appears, reading "Johnson & Johnson proposes paying $8.9 billion to settle talcum powder lawsuits," with a stock market ticker and the Johnson & Johnson logo in the background. The scene transitions to a serene beach at sunset, with the text "TALC AND ASBESTOS TOGETHER FOREVER" overlaid. The video concludes with a humorous comparison between a drawing of a girl and a piece of asbestos, with the text "other girls:" and "me: Asbestos" in black letters.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a topic by outlining the information he will cover. His tone is informative. This transitions to an abrupt musical stinger, seemingly in the style of a dramatic trailer. Afterward, the male speaker resumes, stating "Let's start off with what asbestos actually is." He explains that asbestos is a readily available mineral, made of silicon and oxygen. He lists other silicates and notes asbestos often occurs together with talc, further explaining asbestos takes on a different form.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a detailed figurine of a character lounging on a tree stump, holding a book, with the text "Weta Workshop" displayed in the bottom left corner. The scene transitions to a close-up of a polished black stone with golden needle-like inclusions, labeled "ANTHOPHYLLITE." Following this, a white fibrous mineral is shown, with the text "TENORITE" displayed. The video then shifts to a scenic view of a rocky landscape with a body of water, featuring blue and orange hues, and sparse vegetation. A warning sign about asbestos is shown next, with the text "WARNING" and a description of the health hazards associated with asbestos fibers and dust. The scene then transitions to an aerial view of a mining area with buildings and roads, followed by a news article headline about the eviction of Wittenoom's last resident due to asbestos contamination. The video concludes with a close-up of a warning sign in multiple languages, cautioning about asbestos in the area, with the text "DANGER" and "ASBESTOS IN THIS AREA DO NOT STOP" prominently displayed.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker matter-of-factly listing different kinds of asbestos, including chrysotile and crocidolite, and providing details about their prevalence and historical use, with particular emphasis on the town of Wittenoom, Australia. The speaker mentions that in 2022, Wittenoom's last president was evicted due to asbestos concerns, though people still sneak in to take pictures. Suddenly, a brief, intense burst of static cuts in.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a close-up of a person's face, overlaid with the text "HOW DOES IT HURT YOU" in bold white letters, set against a dark background. The scene transitions to a promotional image for the video game "Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege," featuring two teams of soldiers in tactical gear, with the text "DELUXE EDITION" prominently displayed. Following this, an arrow is shown hitting the bullseye of a target, symbolizing precision. The narrative then shifts to a laboratory setting where individuals in white lab coats are working with scientific equipment, including a glowing red flask. A close-up of a DNA strand being manipulated with tweezers is shown, followed by a periodic table element display for oxygen, with the text "Oxygen 15.999" and the atomic number "8." The video then depicts a person sitting on a beach, facing the ocean, with the word "LUNG" in large red letters superimposed over the scene. The final frames show a microscopic view of a single-celled organism, possibly a protozoan, with intricate details visible under magnification. The video concludes with a black screen, indicating the end of the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a low, ominous organ chord, setting a slightly unsettling tone. This shifts to a male speaker, conversational and calm, who says "I suppose this isn't toxic in the same way as like Battle Snake poison." He details the dangers of asbestos and how it causes cancer through several theories. As he concludes his discussion, the organ music returns, maintaining its ominous tone from the beginning of the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person dressed in a black outfit with lace details, standing next to a rustic wooden wall. They are seen placing a black clay pot on a wooden stump, accompanied by a bundle of straw and a knife. The person then proceeds to add straw into the pot, suggesting a traditional or historical method of preparation. The scene transitions to a display of three ancient clay pots with intricate designs, showcasing their historical significance. The video then shifts to a modern setting, featuring a person dressed in a Spider-Man costume standing between the doors of a subway train, holding onto the sides with a web-like material stretched across the doors. The final scene presents a screenshot of an academic article titled "Fiberglass Grids as Sustainable Reinforcement of Historic Masonry," discussing the use of fiber-reinforced polymers (FRP) materials for strengthening historic masonry structures. The article highlights the effectiveness of GRP (Glass Fiber Reinforced Polymers) in reinforcing historic masonry and mentions the degradation of tensile strength in GRP grids after 450 days of storage in a deionized water and NaCl solution. The video juxtaposes traditional practices with modern superhero imagery and academic research, creating a diverse narrative that spans historical, contemporary, and scholarly themes.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker matter-of-factly stating, "People have been making stuff out of asbestos about as long as they've been making stuff." He proceeds to explain that asbestos has been used for thousands of years to strengthen materials, drawing a parallel to modern fiberglass use. A short musical interlude follows.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a worn-out white cloth on a wooden surface, transitioning to a panoramic view of ancient ruins, possibly the Acropolis in Athens, bathed in the warm glow of the setting sun. The scene shifts to a serene image of a Buddha statue in a meditative pose, surrounded by intricate carvings and floral decorations, evoking a sense of tranquility. A person in a long robe is then shown holding a lantern in a dimly lit cave, creating an atmosphere of mystery and exploration. The narrative continues with a man in a white shirt with the word 'ASBESTOS' printed on it, standing next to a rusted metal structure, suggesting an industrial or hazardous environment. The video then features a regal figure adorned with a crown and holding a scepter, accompanied by the text 'Loves TableCloths,' adding a whimsical touch. The scene transitions to a whimsical depiction of a frying pan with bacon and eggs, animated with a face and the text 'Yummy!' as it cooks over a campfire, adding a playful element. The video concludes with a dramatic visual of a fire and smoke swirling in the dark, creating a sense of intensity and movement.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker describing how asbestos cloth was used by many ancient civilizations, including Egypt, Greece, Rome, China, Persia, and India. He cites its uses in temples and tombs for lantern wicks, and in ceremonial dress like king's tablecloths. He recounts the story of Charlemagne burning dirty tablecloths, then pulling them out clean as a demonstration. He proposes this may be part of why those in his former empire love burning things. He speaks in an informational and slightly amused tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing against a white background, wearing a dark jacket with a lighter stripe across the chest. Bold text reading 'ANOTHER ONE' appears on the screen, accompanied by a signature in the bottom right corner. The scene transitions to a foggy forest where a white bag lies on the ground, suggesting a mysterious or eerie atmosphere. The video then shifts to a large bonfire burning intensely at night, with flames illuminating the surrounding darkness. Following this, a banana is shown on a piece of aluminum foil, with a knife cutting into it, revealing its soft interior. The banana is then wrapped in foil and placed on a grill, indicating preparation for cooking. The final scene displays the cooked banana, now topped with chocolate chips and a dollop of whipped cream, suggesting a dessert-like treat. The video combines elements of mystery, cooking, and indulgence, creating a visually engaging narrative.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing an "interesting use" for asbestos cloth, specifically its use in royal cremations, and then transitioning to a related home experience suggestion involving a banana, chocolate, marshmallows, and an oven. The speaker has a conversational, slightly humorous tone. This is followed by silence.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a painting of a man in a red robe lying down, adorned with a crown and surrounded by ornate decorations, suggesting a historical or religious figure. The scene transitions to an oval portrait of a man in a red robe holding a book, set against a golden background, indicating a scholarly or authoritative figure. The narrative then shifts to an animated character in a blue costume, resembling a superhero, with the text "VERY INTERESTING" displayed, hinting at a moment of contemplation or intrigue. Following this, a close-up of a yellow animated character with red cheeks and large eyes appears, expressing surprise or excitement. The video then presents a statue of a seated figure, identified by the text "PLINY THE YOUNGER," suggesting a historical or literary reference. The scene transitions to a logo reading "UNSOLVED MYSTERIES," indicating a theme of enigma or investigation. The final frame shows two men in a social setting, with one man in a brown jacket and pink shirt gesturing towards another in a maroon hoodie. The text "SICK REFERENCE BRO" and "YOUR REFERENCES ARE OUT OF CONTROL, EVERYONE KNOWS THAT" appears, suggesting a humorous or critical commentary on the use of references in conversation. The video combines historical, animated, and contemporary elements, creating a diverse and engaging narrative.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Marco Polo, the pool game inventor, and his accounts of seeing asbestos mines. He mentions that people knew the health risks of asbestos, possibly referencing Pliny the Elder or Younger's description of miners getting lung issues. The speaker notes that the original source material for this claim is missing, though it is referenced in books from that time. Throughout the clip, there is background music with a calm mood, likely featuring string instruments.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a scene from a social gathering where two men are engaged in a conversation. One man, wearing a brown jacket and a pink shirt, is gesturing animatedly while the other, dressed in a maroon hoodie, listens attentively. The text overlay reads 'SICK REFERENCE BRO' and 'YOUR REFERENCES ARE OUT OF CONTROL, EVERYONE KNOWS THAT,' suggesting a humorous or critical commentary on the man's behavior. The scene transitions to a close-up of a white mineral specimen with a fibrous texture, placed on a light-colored fabric background, highlighting its natural beauty and intricate details. The video then shifts to a historical black-and-white photograph of a street scene, depicting people in period clothing, including a woman in a long dress and apron, and a man in a hat, walking along a cobblestone street lined with buildings. The atmosphere is nostalgic, capturing a moment from the past. Following this, another black-and-white photograph shows a mining operation with a small train and a crane amidst rocky terrain, emphasizing the industrial and labor-intensive nature of the work. The video continues with a scene inside a factory, where workers are diligently operating machinery, surrounded by tools and equipment, illustrating the industrious environment. The narrative then moves to a close-up of a small figurine made of coins, placed on a reflective surface, with a blurred background featuring a window, adding a whimsical touch. The final scene presents an aerial view of a large open-pit mine with terraced levels and a body of water at the bottom, showcasing the scale and impact of mining activities on the landscape. The video effectively combines social commentary, natural beauty, historical context, industrial scenes, and whimsical elements, creating a diverse and engaging visual narrative.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with an alarm sound. This transitions into a male speaker discussing the history of asbestos, describing its rise to prominence during the Industrial Revolution, its use in mining equipment, and the need for fireproof insulation in factories. He mentions the creation of large asbestos mines in various locations. Throughout, a consistent, upbeat musical score plays in the background.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with an aerial view of a rugged landscape featuring a winding road and a cluster of buildings nestled in a valley, surrounded by rocky hills and sparse vegetation. The scene transitions to an animated underwater setting, where a character with a red hood and white tail is seen in a sunlit cave filled with various objects, including bottles and pottery. The narrative then shifts to a close-up of a damaged tiled floor, revealing cracks and broken pieces, followed by a view of a deteriorated wall with a hole, exposing the underlying structure. The video then presents a black-and-white photograph of three individuals in protective suits, standing in a line, with a forested background. The final scene shows a theater stage with a large sign reading 'Asbestos' in bold letters, accompanied by decorative elements, indicating a historical or thematic reference to the hazardous material. The video concludes with a focus on the stage's ornate details and the word 'Asbestos,' emphasizing the theme of decay and historical significance.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing asbestos, mentioning its use in floor tiles, fireproof doors, fire suits, and curtains in theaters due to fire-related issues. The speaker maintains a casual and informative tone. This is followed by a brief and indistinct sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a sepia-toned image of a theater interior, showcasing rows of seats and ornate architectural details, suggesting a historical or vintage setting. It transitions to a close-up of a box labeled 'CHRYSTOTILE Balanced BRAKE SET' by the Canadian Tire Corporation, highlighting its features such as 'Longer Service,' 'Fewer Adjustments,' 'Smooth Brake Action,' and 'Positive Stopping.' The box is open, revealing the brake set inside, set against a blue fabric background. The scene shifts to a graphic with multiple warning signs and the text 'BONUS ROUND' in bold red and yellow letters, indicating a special segment or feature. Following this, a close-up of a worn, circular object with a central cavity is shown, possibly a piece of machinery or a tool, placed on a wooden surface. The video then displays a green metal container with Cyrillic text 'ГП-5' and 'М-1-83-63,' suggesting a military or industrial item, placed on a wooden surface. The focus then moves to a white cigarette pack labeled 'KENT CIGARETTES' with 'WITH THE MICRONITE FILTER' and a blue label at the top, set against a blue fabric background. The video concludes with a split-screen view: on the left, a close-up of a cigarette's end, and on the right, a cross-section of a cigarette, revealing its internal structure with blue and beige fibers, emphasizing the cigarette's composition and design.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the history of asbestos use, noting its use in brake pads and surprising applications like dental casts, wine filtering, and gas mask filters. He then mentions a company called Kent that created cigarettes, "that their filter was filled with blue asbestos and crepe paper." The speaker concludes by saying, "In the world of RPGs, this is called stacking debuffs." The speech is delivered in an informative and slightly conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a detailed infographic titled "The Comprehensive Destiny 2 Global Buffs, Global Debuffs, Modifiers, Perks/Mods, & more Damage Statistical Catalogue," updated on 8 September 2020, featuring various icons and a green banner. It transitions to a kitchen scene where a person mixes a sauce in a white bowl, followed by a vintage advertisement for "Hardie's Fibrolite" promoting cost-effective home building. The narrative then shifts to a black-and-white photograph of a jubilant crowd holding "Peace" signs, suggesting a post-war celebration. A modern-day scene shows a person with curly hair, wearing a white t-shirt and blue jeans, gesturing with their hands against a neutral background. The video then displays a two-story house with a green roof and white walls, surrounded by lush greenery, indicating a serene residential area. The final scene features a webpage from WorkSafe.qld.gov.au, discussing the use of high-pressure water spray equipment on asbestos roofs, highlighting safety concerns and the spread of asbestos-contaminated dust and debris. The video effectively juxtaposes historical and contemporary elements, emphasizing the evolution of building materials and safety practices.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing asbestos being mixed with concrete to create panels for house exteriors, mentioning the product name "fibrolite". His tone is informative. He continues describing that these were used frequently post-WWII, especially in England, and notes a special law in Queensland, Australia about cleaning asbestos houses. A new, different male voice interjects with the exclamation "What the fuck is going on in here on this day?". The clip concludes with a brief, indistinct sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a shiny disco ball reflecting light, set against a dark background, creating a festive atmosphere. It transitions to a list of countries, each accompanied by its flag, displayed in a grid format, suggesting a global theme. The scene then shifts to a bustling city street, likely Times Square in New York City, filled with people and vibrant billboards, capturing the lively urban environment. Following this, a legal document titled "Corrosion Proof Fittings v. EPA, 947 F.2d 1201 (5th Cir. 1991)" is shown, indicating a focus on legal matters. The video then moves to a close-up of a book, possibly a novel, with text visible on the page, hinting at a literary theme. A summary of the Clean Air Act is presented, detailing its purpose and regulations, with quick links to additional resources. The scene transitions to an outdoor view of a large, rusted industrial tank, emphasizing the impact of air pollution. The video concludes with a cozy indoor scene featuring a fireplace with a roaring fire, surrounded by candles and greenery, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. Throughout the video, the narrative seamlessly transitions from a festive disco ball to a global perspective, legal and environmental themes, and finally to a comforting indoor setting, showcasing a diverse range of subjects and environments.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing asbestos, stating it "should be banned or heavily regulated in the 80s and 90s by most countries." He lists countries with complete bans and explains the EPA's failed attempt to ban it completely in the US, with mention of a court case and some successful limited bans. He goes on to explain that the Clean Air Act also banned it in some applications, and that the Consumer Product Safety Act bans it from artificial fireplace embers and wall patching compounds. He concludes by saying the FDA has largely gotten asbestos out of pharmaceuticals and food.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a yellow jacket passionately singing into a microphone on stage, his hand raised in a gesture of expression. The scene transitions to a close-up of a circular object with the text 'MADE IN USA' and 'DSC' visible, suggesting it is a manufactured item. Next, a stack of concrete pipes is shown, followed by a man in a dimly lit room wearing protective gear, possibly indicating a work environment. The video then shifts to a nighttime view of a tower with the text '16%' overlaid, followed by an aerial view of a city with '11.5%' displayed, and an industrial site with '70%' text, hinting at statistics related to these locations. The video concludes with a map of Indonesia, highlighting the country's geographical context. Throughout the video, the scenes transition smoothly, connecting various elements through visual and textual cues.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker informing the audience about asbestos, mentioning its current uses like "automobile clutches, break pads, corrugated sheeting," and roofing materials. His tone is informative and neutral. He goes on to state that Russia, Kazakhstan, China, and Brazil are the largest asbestos miners. The speaker then states, "About 70% of actual products being made out of asbestos are made in Asia," naming China, India, and Indonesia as the largest producers, before concluding with the question, "What do we do with all this asbestos?"

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a chef in a kitchen, wearing a white chef's coat and a black and white striped apron, preparing a dish. He is seen adding ingredients to a container filled with a red liquid, possibly a sauce or soup. The kitchen is well-equipped, with a marble countertop, a stack of plates, and various kitchen utensils visible. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting, showcasing a stone structure resembling a dolmen, surrounded by grass and rocks, indicating a historical or archaeological site. The video then shifts to a close-up of hands unwrapping a loaf of bread from brown paper, suggesting a focus on food preparation or consumption. Following this, the video displays various minerals, including Feldspar, Mica, Olivine, Quartz, and Pyroxene, each labeled with their names, indicating an educational segment about geology or mineralogy. The next scene shows a close-up of an oven control panel with temperature settings, displaying "1000°C" and "1800°F," followed by a hand adjusting the temperature to "1250°C" and "2300°F," emphasizing high-temperature cooking or baking. The video then transitions to a microwave oven, where a hand is seen opening the door and placing a plate inside, with the microwave's digital display showing "5," possibly indicating a cooking time. The video concludes with a focus on the microwave, highlighting its interior and the surrounding kitchen environment, which includes various kitchen items and utensils, suggesting a domestic setting.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how asbestos is typically disposed of, mentioning "putting it in containers that are airtight and burying it" in marked landfills. He then shifts to discussing permanent disposal methods, like "turning it into other things" by melting it down above certain temperatures to eliminate the fibrous form. He notes it can become "silicate glass" or even ceramic and porcelain with the help of microwaves, or be dissolved with oxalic acid and ultrasounds. The speaker's tone is informative and conversational.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a laptop screen displaying a webpage from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) about state asbestos contacts. The webpage provides information on how to contact state departments of environmental protection or health for asbestos-related inquiries and training courses. The scene then transitions to a Wikipedia page titled "List of environmental organizations," detailing various global and intergovernmental organizations focused on environmental issues. Following this, the video shows a bright yellow sticky note with the handwritten message "Don't Touch!" taped to a black background, emphasizing a warning or caution. The video concludes with a repetition of the same sticky note, reinforcing the message.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with speech from a single male speaker. He advises on what to do if you find something made of asbestos, suggesting calling the EPA in the US or similar organizations in other countries, and emphasizing the importance of not moving it or scraping it to prevent fibers from getting into the air. He speaks in a conversational, informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a mesmerizing display of golden glitter particles floating and shimmering in the air, creating a magical and festive atmosphere. The glitter particles vary in size and brightness, reflecting light in a way that gives the scene a dynamic and sparkling effect. The background is dark, which enhances the contrast and makes the glitter stand out even more vividly. The scene then transitions to a close-up of a person's foot with the word "BYE" written on the sole in black marker. The foot is positioned on a light-colored surface, and the person is wearing dark pants. The word "BYE" suggests a farewell or goodbye gesture. The video then shifts to a black screen with the word "Subscribe" written in bold white letters, encouraging viewers to subscribe to a channel or service. The word "Subscribe" is repeated several times, emphasizing the call to action. The video concludes with the same black screen and white text, reinforcing the message to subscribe.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker in a casual tone, who ends with a lighthearted, somewhat humorous warning about the material asbestos. This is immediately followed by a loud whooshing sound, suggesting a passing vehicle or rush of air.
